intro: Corydalis humilis, commonly known as the dwarf corydalis, is a herbaceous perennial native to the mountainous regions of Asia. It typically grows to a height of about 10–20 centimeters, featuring slender stems and small, clustered flowers that range in color from pink to purple. The plant produces distinctive, spiral-shaped seed pods that contain numerous tiny seeds. It thrives in well-drained soils and partial shade, often found in woodland or rocky habitats. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it is cultivated in gardens and traditional herbal practices.
